[[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] | manageryears2 = 2019– | managerclubs2 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] }} '''Frank James Lampard''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|OBE}} (born 20 June 1978) is an English professional [[Manager (association football)|football manager]] and former [[Football player|player]] who is the head coach of {{English football updater|Chelsea}} club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. As a player, he is widely considered to be one of Chelsea's greatest ever players, and one of the greatest midfielders of his generation. A creative and technically gifted [[Midfielder#Box-to-box midfielder|box-to-box midfielder]], Lampard began his career in 1995 at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], the club where his father, [[Frank Lampard (footballer, born 1948)|Frank Lampard Sr.]], also played. He is best known for his time at London rivals Chelsea, whom he signed for in 2001 for £11 million. In his thirteen years with the club, Lampard established himself as a prolific scorer from midfield, becoming Chelsea's [[List of Chelsea F.C. records and statistics#All-time top goalscorers|all-time leading goalscorer]], with 211 goals scored in all competitions.{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/recap-frank-lampard-joins-new-3631773|title=Frank Lampard joins New York City – reaction as Chelsea veteran quits Stamford Bridge|first=Richard|last=Beech|newspaper=Daily Mirror|location=London|accessdate=13 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903091259/http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/recap-frank-lampard-joins-new-3631773|archive-date=3 September 2014|url-status=live}} He also won three [[Premier League]] titles, a [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League]] title, four [[FA Cup]]s, a [[2013 UEFA Europa League Final|UEFA Europa League]] title, and two [[EFL Cup|Football League Cup]]s. In 2005, he was named [[FWA Footballer of the Year]], and finished runner-up for both the [[2005 Ballon d'Or|Ballon d'Or]] and [[2005 FIFA World Player of the Year|FIFA World Player of the Year]] awards. After leaving Chelsea, Lampard played for league rivals [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) club [[New York City FC|New York City]] before retiring in 2017.{{cite news|url=http://m.bbc.com/sport/football/30647043|title=Man City extend Lampard contract|first=David|last=Ornstein|publisher=BBC Sport|location=London|accessdate=31 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102163732/http://m.bbc.com/sport/football/30647043|archive-date=2 January 2015|url-status=live}}{{cite news|title=Frank Lampard: New York City sign ex-Chelsea midfielder|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28188979|accessdate=24 July 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120072058/http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28188979|archive-date=20 January 2018|url-status=live}} Lampard is one of nine players, and the only midfielder, to have scored [[List of Premier League players with 100 or more goals|150 or more goals]] in the Premier League. He is fourth in the Premier League's all-time assists ranking, with 102 assists.{{cite web | url = http://www.premiersoccerstats.com/Records.cfm?DOrderby=Ass&DYearby=All%20Seasons | title = All Time Player Records | publisher = premiersoccerstats.com | accessdate = 6 December 2013 | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131204174344/http://www.premiersoccerstats.com/Records.cfm?DOrderby=Ass&DYearby=All%20Seasons | archivedate = 4 December 2013 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/Statistics |title=Players |accessdate=13 September 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111127233054/http://www.premierleague.com/page/Statistics |archivedate=27 November 2011 |df=dmy }} Lampard also holds a number of Chelsea and additional Premier League [[Frank Lampard#Records|records]], and has won [[PFA Fans' Player of the Year]] and the [[FWA Tribute Award]]. During his career, he was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]] three times, finished as the Premier League's top assist provider three times, and was named in the [[FIFPro World XI]] and a [[MLS All-Star]]. He was named in the Chelsea Team of the Decade as voted for by Chelsea fans.{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2019/12/31/chelsea-team-of-the-decade---the-supporters--choice-unveiled0|title=Chelsea Team of the decade|first=Aditya|last=M S|website=Chelsea FC.|accessdate=13 September 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/579327-world-football-the-top-ten-midfielders-of-the-past-decade#slide0|title=World Football: The Top 10 Midfielders of the Past Decade|first=Aditya|last=M S|website=Bleacher Report|accessdate=13 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223085822/http://bleacherreport.com/articles/579327-world-football-the-top-ten-midfielders-of-the-past-decade#slide0|archive-date=23 December 2014|url-status=live}} At international level, Lampard played [[List of men's footballers with 100 or more international caps|106 matches]] for the [[England national football team|England national team]], after making his debut in 1999. He represented his country at three [[FIFA World Cup]]s – in [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006]], [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010]] and [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]] – and in [[UEFA Euro 2004]], where he was named in the team of the tournament. Lampard scored 29 goals for England, and was voted [[England Player of the Year]] in 2004 and 2005. He is also England's most prolific penalty taker, with nine goals scored from the spot. After retiring from international football, he was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in 2015 for his services to football.{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/11958152/Duke-of-Cambridge-awards-Frank-Lampard-OBE-for-services-to-football.html|title=Duke of Cambridge awards Frank Lampard OBE for services to football|date=27 October 2015|website=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=4 July 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190704203824/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/11958152/Duke-of-Cambridge-awards-Frank-Lampard-OBE-for-services-to-football.html|archive-date=4 July 2019|url-status=live}} After retiring, Lampard served as a team captain on the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] sport panel show ''[[Play to the Whistle]]'' from 2015 until 2017. He has also written a number of children's books.{{Cite web|url=https://www.balls.ie/football/frank-lampards-childrens-books-genius-328882|title=Why Frank Lampard's Children's Books Are Works Of Great Literary Genius|website=Balls.ie|access-date=4 July 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190704205327/https://www.balls.ie/football/frank-lampards-childrens-books-genius-328882|archive-date=4 July 2019|url-status=live}} He began his coaching career with [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] in 2018, leading the club to the final of that season's [[2019 EFL Championship play-off Final|play-offs]]. He was appointed as Chelsea's head coach a year later. ==Club career== ===West Ham United=== Lampard began his career at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], [[Frank Lampard (footballer, born 1948)|his father]]'s former club, joining the youth team in 1994, his schoolboy hero being West Ham striker, [[Frank McAvennie]].{{cite web|url=http://au.fourfourtwo.com/features/6852,to-be-frank-lampard.aspx |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220161305/http://au.fourfourtwo.com/features/6852%2Cto-be-frank-lampard.aspx |archivedate=20 February 2011 |title=To be Frank...Lampard |publisher=FourFourTwo |accessdate=28 November 2013 |url-status=dead }} Lampard joined West Ham when his father was the assistant coach, entering as an apprentice in the youth team in 1994 and signing a professional contract the following year. He went on loan to [[Football League One|Second Division]] [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in October 1995, debuting in his team's victory 2–0 over [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] and scoring his first career goal in a match against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]. Lampard played nine times for Swansea before returning to West Ham in January 1996. ====1995–97: Development==== Lampard made his debut for West Ham on 31 January 1996 against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[John Moncur]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3987&united=31_Jan_1996 | title=Game played 31 January 1996 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014010743/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=3987&united=31_Jan_1996 | archive-date=14 October 2013 | url-status=live }} His only other game of the season was the season's last, on 5 May 1996, a 1–1 home draw with [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] when Lampard was used as a substitute for [[Keith Rowland]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=394&united=Frank_Jnr_Lampard | title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics Frank Jnr Lampard | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013225618/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=394&united=Frank_Jnr_Lampard | archive-date=13 October 2013 | url-status=live }} The following season Lampard made his first start for West Ham, on 17 August 1996, in a 2–0 away defeat to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] before being substituted for [[Robbie Slater]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4005&united=17_Aug_1996 | title=Game played 17 August 1996 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014021438/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4005&united=17_Aug_1996 | archive-date=14 October 2013 | url-status=live }} Lampard's season ended on 15 March 1997 when he sustained a broken leg during an away, 0–0 draw, against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. Carried from the pitch on a stretcher, his 31st-minute substitute was [[Rio Ferdinand]]. The game also saw his first [[Yellow card (sports)|booking]] as a West Ham player.{{cite web | url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/aston-villa-v-west-ham-united-15-march-1997-22840/ | title=Aston Villa v West Ham United | publisher=11v11.com | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202222101/http://www.11v11.com/matches/aston-villa-v-west-ham-united-15-march-1997-22840/ | archive-date=2 December 2013 | url-status=live }}{{cite news | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11668/2385820/ | title=Lampard hits out at Hammers | publisher=www1.skysports.com | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203005053/http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11668/2385820/ | archive-date=3 December 2013 | url-status=live }} Lampard claims to have been jeered from the pitch by [[West Ham United F.C. supporters|West Ham United supporters]], an action which made him consider leaving football. He had made 16 appearances in all competitions for The Hammers. ====1997–99: First team regular==== From this season Lampard took the number 18 squad number having previously held the number 26 spot. On the first day of the [[1997–98 West Ham United F.C. season|1997–98 season]], West Ham opened their fixtures with an away game against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] who were playing in the top tier of English football for the first time in 110 years. Lampard came on as a 76th-minute substitute for [[Eyal Berkovic]]. Barely a minute later he scored what was the winning goal in a 2–1 win for The Hammers having received the ball from [[Michael Hughes (footballer)|Michael Hughes]] and flicking it past Barnsley goalkeeper [[David Watson (footballer, born 1973)|David Watson]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4050&united=09_Aug_1997 | title=Game played 9 August 1997 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202232309/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4050&united=09_Aug_1997 | archive-date=2 December 2013 | url-status=live }} The season also saw his first [[Hat-trick (association football)|hat-trick]]. On 19 November 1997, West Ham played [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] in a [[1997–98 Football League Cup|League Cup]], fourth-round game. Lampard's three goals plus another from [[John Hartson]] were enough to beat Walsall who responded via a goal from [[Andy Watson (footballer, born 1967)|Andy Watson]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4066&united=19_Nov_1997 | title=Game played 19 November 1997 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202221959/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4066&united=19_Nov_1997 | archive-date=2 December 2013 | url-status=live }} Lampard made 42 appearances for the 1997–98 season in all competitions scoring nine goals. Lampard was an ever-present for West Ham in the [[1998–99 West Ham United F.C. season|1998–99 season]], helping his team to fifth place in the [[1998–99 Premier League]] and qualification for the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup]]. This is the highest West Ham have ever come in the league.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1999&united=Premier_League_1998-99 | title=Premier League 1998–99 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202232857/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=1999&united=Premier_League_1998-99 | archive-date=2 December 2013 | url-status=live }}{{cite web | url=http://www.officialplayersites.com/managers/manager.php?id=32 | title=Harry Redknapp | publisher=officialplayersites.com | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111004301/http://www.officialplayersites.com/managers/manager.php?id=32 | archive-date=11 November 2014 | url-status=live }} ====1999–2001: New contract and departure==== Before the start of the [[1999–2000 FA Premier League]] season, Lampard signed an extension to his contract which would have kept him with the club until 2005.{{cite web | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-60446027.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610060643/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-60446027.html | url-status=dead | archive-date=10 June 2014 | title=Football: Lampard's cracker; West Ham United 1 Heerenveen 0.(Sport) | publisher=highbeam.com | accessdate=29 November 2013}} Having qualified for the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup#1995–2005|Intertoto Cup]], West Ham's season started early, in July 1999. On 24 July 1999, Lampard scored his first goal in European football in a 1–1 away draw with Finnish side [[FC Jokerit|Jokerit]].{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4142&united=24_Jul_1999 | title=Game played 24 July 1999 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020163753/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4142&united=24_Jul_1999 | archive-date=20 October 2013 | url-status=live }} Another goal in the semi-final against [[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]] put West Ham into the final against [[FC Metz|Metz]]. Despite losing the first leg 1–0 in London, West Ham won 3–1 in France on 24 August 1999 with goals from [[Trevor Sinclair]], [[Paulo Wanchope]] and Lampard.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4149&united=24_Aug_1999 | title=Game played 24 August 1999 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104063925/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4149&united=24_Aug_1999 | archive-date=4 November 2013 | url-status=live }} Winning the competition saw West Ham in the [[1999–2000 UEFA Cup]]. Lampard scored his first goal in this competition on 16 September 1999, in a 3–0 home win against [[NK Osijek|Osijek]], a tie which they won 6–1 on aggregate.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4186&united=16_Sep_1999 | title=Game played 16 September 1999 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104065137/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=5&ham=4186&united=16_Sep_1999 | archive-date=4 November 2013 | url-status=live }} This season also saw West Ham beat [[Bradford City F.C.|Bradford City]] 5–4 at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] in February 2000. The game received notoriety for Lampard's fight over the ball with [[Paolo Di Canio]]. With West Ham 4–2 down they gained a penalty. Lampard was West Ham's regular penalty taker. Di Canio, however, wanted to take the kick and the two tussled over the ball with Di Canio winning and scoring to make the game 4–3 to West Ham.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=E0WUkWwx38AC&pg=PT93&lpg=PT93&dq=bradford+city+5-4+di+canio+lampard#v=onepage|title=Harry Redknapp – The Autobiography|publisher=John Blake publishing|first=Harry|last=Redknapp|date=7 November 2011|isbn=9781843589426}}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sport/football/fa_carling_premiership/640512.stm|title=West Ham 5–4 Bradford City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 February 2000|accessdate=28 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202233329/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sport/football/fa_carling_premiership/640512.stm|archive-date=2 December 2013|url-status=live}} In the [[1999–2000 West Ham United F.C. season|1999–2000]], season he finished as the club's third top scorer, behind Di Canio and Paulo Wanchope, with a total of 14 goals.{{cite web|url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=2000&united=Premier_League_1999-2000|title=Premier League 1999–2000|publisher=westhamstats.info|accessdate=28 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112045420/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=2000&united=Premier_League_1999-2000|archive-date=12 November 2013|url-status=live}} In the [[2000–01 West Ham United F.C. season|2000–01 season]], West Ham's form suffered. They spent most of the season in the bottom half of the Premier League table.{{cite web | url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=2001&united=Premier_League_2000-01 | title=Premier League 2000–01 | publisher=westhamstats.info | accessdate=28 November 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112045425/http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=4&ham=2001&united=Premier_League_2000-01 | archive-date=12 November 2013 | url-status=live }} From fifth place the previous season they finished 15th. Despite this Lampard scored 9 goals in 37 games behind only [[Frédéric Kanouté]] and Di Canio. In May 2001, his uncle [[Harry Redknapp]] left the club by mutual consent after seven years in the role.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/3005096/Redknapp-leaves-West-Ham.html|title=Redknapp leaves West Ham|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=9 May 2001|accessdate=28 November 2013|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101114358/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/3005096/Redknapp-leaves-West-Ham.html|archive-date=1 January 2014|url-status=live}} His father Frank also left the club and Lampard, under the pressure of being known as "Frank Lampard's son" and the poor treatment of his father by West Ham, decided to move to another club.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/henrywinter/2426031/On-the-Spot-Frank-Lampard.html|title=On the spot – Frank Lampard|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=29 November 2003|accessdate=28 November 2013|last=Winter|first=Henry|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103095820/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/henrywinter/2426031/On-the-Spot-Frank-Lampard.html|archive-date=3 January 2014|url-status=live}} He left West Ham for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for £11 million in June 2001, the Hammers having previously declined a £15 million joint bid from [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] for Lampard and Frédéric Kanouté.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/1383370.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|title=Chelsea agree £11m Lampard deal|date=11 June 2001|access-date=18 December 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121217122138/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/1383370.stm|archive-date=17 December 2012|url-status=live}} ===Chelsea=== ====2001–04: Signing and first team breakthrough==== [[File:Frank Lampard in the rain - geograph.org.uk - 1608772.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Lampard in 2004]] Lampard's Premier League debut with Chelsea came on 19 August 2001 in a 1–1 draw with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], while his first red card came in a match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 16 September 2001. Lampard appeared in all of Chelsea's league matches and scored eight goals in the 2001–02 season. He netted the match-winner in Chelsea's [[2002–03 FA Premier League|2002–03]] season-opener against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. The [[2003–04 FA Premier League|following season]], he was selected as the [[Premier League Player of the Month]] in September 2003, and the PFA Fans' Player of the Month in October. Chelsea finished second in the 2003–04 [[Premier League]] behind unbeaten [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and he was named in the 2004 [[PFA Team of the Year]] as he reached double figures in league goals (10) for the first time in his career, in addition to four goals in fourteen [[2003–04 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] matches, as Chelsea advanced to the [[2003–04 UEFA Champions League#Semi-finals|semi-finals]]. In the semi-final against [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] he scored, but Chelsea lost 5–3 on aggregate.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/champions_league/3680039.stm|title=Chelsea 2–2 Monaco|accessdate=13 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170828022245/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/champions_league/3680039.stm|archive-date=28 August 2017|url-status=live}} At the end of the season, he came second behind [[Thierry Henry]] for the 2004 [[FWA Footballer of the Year]] award.{{cite news |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2004-05/11/content_329610.htm |title=Henry named FWA player of year |newspaper=China Daily |date=11 May 2004 |accessdate=1 March 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301234536/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2004-05/11/content_329610.htm |archive-date=1 March 2014 |url-status=live }} ====2004–06: Back-to-back Premier League wins==== [[File:Champions 2004-5.jpg|thumb|Lampard celebrates winning the 2004–05 Premiership with [[Eiður Guðjohnsen]] and [[John Terry]].]] Lampard played in all 38 Premier League matches for the third consecutive season in [[2004–05 FA Premier League|2004–05]]. He finished with 13 goals (19 in all competitions), in addition to leading the league in assists with 16.{{cite news|date=7 July 2008 |url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/Statistics/0,,12306,00.html |title=Premier League Statistics |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=7 July 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230130252/http://www.premierleague.com/page/Statistics/0%2C%2C12306%2C00.html |archivedate=30 December 2010 |df=dmy }} In August 2004, he scored the winning goal against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in the Premier League,{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/3586098.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | title=Chelsea 2–1 Southampton | date=28 August 2004 | access-date=18 June 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110114009/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/3586098.stm | archive-date=10 January 2014 | url-status=live }} and continued scoring important goals as he scored both in a 2–0 win against Tottenham.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/4150639.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Tottenham 0–2 Chelsea | date=15 January 2005 | access-date=18 June 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904041021/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/4150639.stm | archive-date=4 September 2013 | url-status=live }} In March 2005 he scored a long-range goal from 30 yards against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in the Premier League which Chelsea won 4–1. Lampard continued his season strongly, and his brilliant performances for Chelsea in the Premier League and [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] further increased his reputation as one of the best midfielders in the world. In the [[2004–05 UEFA Champions League|2004–05 Champions League]], he scored one of the goals in Chelsea's famous 4–2 win over [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], helping Chelsea to progress to the quarter-finals.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/4321491.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | title=Chelsea 4–2 Barcelona | date=8 March 2005 | access-date=18 June 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501224019/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/4321491.stm | archive-date=1 May 2009 | url-status=live }} In the quarter-finals, he scored three goals in two legs against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] as Chelsea won 6–5 on aggregate. His second goal in the first leg was a spectacular one; he controlled [[Claude Makélélé]]'s cross with his chest then turned and swivelled and sent the ball inside the far post with a left-foot half volley.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2004/matches/round=1970/match=1084882/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Stylish Chelsea seize command|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=13 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229122028/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2004/matches/round=1970/match=1084882/postmatch/report/index.html|archive-date=29 December 2014|url-status=live}} In April 2005, Lampard scored both goals against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in a 2–0 win which was the Premier League title-winning match for Chelsea, which also won the first major trophy of his career as Chelsea bagged their first top-flight title in 50 years, by a 12-point margin. He was named as Barclays Player of the Season for 2004–05.{{cite web |url=http://www.4thegame.com/club/chelsea-fc/player-profile/1125/franklampard.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090726073229/http://www.4thegame.com/club/chelsea-fc/player-profile/1125/franklampard.html|archivedate=26 July 2009|title=Frank Lampard |publisher=4thegame|accessdate=5 May 2014}} Though Chelsea were eliminated in the [[2004–05 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] [[UEFA Champions League 2004-05#Semi-finals|semi-finals]] by league rivals [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], they took home the [[2004–05 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]], in which Lampard scored twice in six matches, which included the opening goal against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the League Cup semi-final, which Chelsea won 2–1. He landed his first personal award by being named the 2005 [[FWA Footballer of the Year|Footballer of the Year]].{{cite news | date=6 May 2005| url=http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/050506/7/3lg2.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051127132302/http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/050506/7/3lg2.html |archivedate=27 November 2005 | title=Chelsea's Lampard is writers' player of the year| publisher=Yahoo! | accessdate=6 January 2007}} [[File:Frank Lampard cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Lampard in 2005]] Lampard netted a career-high 16 league goals in [[2005–06 FA Premier League|2005–06]]. In September 2005 he was selected as a member of the inaugural [[FIFPro World XI|World XI]].{{cite news | date=20 December 2005 | url=http://www.thefa.com/England/news/2005/lampard_and_terry_honoured | archive-url=https://archive.today/20140505161924/http://www.thefa.com/England/news/2005/lampard_and_terry_honoured | url-status=dead | archivedate=5 May 2014 | title=Lamps and Terry honoured| publisher=Football Association| accessdate=8 May 2014}} He finished as runner-up to [[Ronaldinho]] for both the [[Ballon d'Or]] and [[2005 FIFA World Player of the Year|FIFA World Player of the Year]] awards.{{cite news | date=28 November 2005 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4475808.stm | title=Ronaldinho scoops European award | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=9 December 2006 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061106034156/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4475808.stm | archive-date=6 November 2006 | url-status=live }}{{cite news | date=19 December 2005 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4475808.stm | title=Ronaldinho wins world award again | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=9 December 2006 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061106034156/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4475808.stm | archive-date=6 November 2006 | url-status=live }} His record of consecutive Premier League appearances ended at 164 (five better than previous record-holder [[David James (footballer, born 1970)|David James]]) on 28 December 2005, when he sat out a match against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] due to illness.{{cite news | date=29 December 2005 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2005/dec/29/newsstory.sport | title=Lampard 164 and out | newspaper=The Guardian | accessdate=8 May 2014 | location=London | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225194758/http://www.theguardian.com/football/2005/dec/29/newsstory.sport | archive-date=25 December 2013 | url-status=live }} Lampard scored 12 goals in his first four months of the 2005–06 season. He scored twice in three separate matches from August to November, including both in a 2–1 win over Aston Villa, making Chelsea the first team to win their first seven matches in the Premier League.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/4255466.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | title=Chelsea 2–1 Aston Villa | date=24 September 2005 | access-date=18 June 2011 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328000558/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/4255466.stm | archive-date=28 March 2012 | url-status=live }} He scored twice again, this time against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in a 4–2 win, which included a free-kick from 25 yards. After the match, manager [[José Mourinho]] hailed Lampard as the "best player in the world". Chelsea eventually won the [[2005–06 FA Premier League|Premier League]] for the second time, in which Lampard was Chelsea's topscorer with 16 league goals. In the [[2005–06 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] group stages, he scored a free-kick against [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]]. Chelsea proggresed to the first knock-out round to face Barcelona, with Lampard scoring a goal in the second leg, but Chelsea were eliminated 3–2 on aggregate. ====2006–11: Domestic and individual success==== [[File:Lampard playing.jpg|thumb|upright|Lampard warming up for Chelsea]] Due to a back injury sustained by [[John Terry]], Lampard spent much of the [[2006–07 FA Premier League|2006–07]] campaign as team captain in his absence. He enjoyed a streak of seven goals in eight games. He scored both goals in a 2–0 win over [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and scored his 77th goal for Chelsea from a long range strike in a 3–2 win over [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 17 December, overtaking [[Dennis Wise]] as Chelsea's highest scoring midfielder.{{cite news | date=17 December 2006| url=http://www.chelseafc.com/matchday-live/match/34534 | archive-url=https://archive.today/20140508101249/http://www.chelseafc.com/matchday-live/match/34534 | url-status=dead | archivedate=8 May 2014 | title=Match Report: Everton 3 Chelsea 2| publisher= Chelsea F.C.| accessdate=8 May 2014}} Then in the [[2006–07 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] group stages he scored a goal from an extremely tight angle against Barcelona, at the [[Camp Nou]], the match ended 2–2. Lampard finished with 21 goals in all competitions, including a career-high six [[2006–07 FA Cup|FA Cup]] goals. He scored his first Chelsea hat-trick in the [[2006–07 FA Cup#Third round proper|third-round tie]] against [[Macclesfield Town F.C.|Macclesfield Town]] on 6 January 2007. He scored two goals to help Chelsea to a [[2006–07 FA Cup#Sixth round proper|quarter-final draw]] with Tottenham Hotspur after having trailed 3–1, and he was named the FA Cup player-of-the-round for his performance.{{cite news | date=30 March 2007 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/6491391.stm | title=Lampard triumphs in FA Cup award | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=9 April 2007 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410141847/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/6491391.stm | archive-date=10 April 2007 | url-status=live }} He gave the assist to [[Didier Drogba]] in the [[2007 FA Cup Final]] which was the winning goal in extra-time, as Chelsea won it 1–0. In a post-match interview following Chelsea's [[2007 FA Cup Final|FA Cup Final]] victory over Manchester United, Lampard said he wanted to stay at the club "forever".{{cite news | date=20 May 2007| url=http://www.eurosport.com/football/fa-cup/2006-2007/sport_sto1186167.shtml|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070521042350/http://www.eurosport.com/football/fa-cup/2006-2007/sport_sto1186167.shtml |archivedate=21 May 2007 | title=Mourinho proud of Chelsea players| publisher=Eurosport | accessdate=20 May 2007}} Lampard's 2007–08 season was hampered by injury. He managed to play 40 matches, 24 of them in the Premier League. This was the fewest league games he had played in a season since 1996–97. On 16 February 2008, Lampard became the eighth Chelsea player to score 100 goals for the club in a 3–1 [[2007–08 FA Cup|FA Cup]] fifth-round win over [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]].{{cite news | date=17 February 2008| url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1243456 | archive-url=https://archive.today/20140508101316/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1243456 | url-status=dead | archivedate=8 May 2014 | title=Frank and the Full 100 Club| publisher=Chelsea F.C. | accessdate=8 May 2014}} After the final whistle, Lampard removed his jersey and flashed a T-shirt to the Chelsea fans with "100 Not Out, They Are All For You, Thanks" printed across the front.https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/feb/18/match.chelsea On 12 March 2008, Lampard scored four goals in a 6–1 rout of [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]]. Then in the second leg of the [[2007–08 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] quarter-final, he scored the winning goal against [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]] in the 87th minute as Chelsea won 3–2 on aggregate. On 30 April, Lampard, grieving the loss of his mother a week earlier, decided to play in the second leg of Chelsea's [[UEFA Champions League 2007-08#Semi-finals|Champions League semi-final against Liverpool]], who were eliminated on 4–3 aggregate as he took an emotional penalty in the 98th minute of extra-time, which he scored confidently. In the [[2008 UEFA Champions League Final|final against Manchester United]], he scored an equalising goal in the 45th minute, as [[Michael Essien]]'s deflected shot found him as he went to the box with his trade-mark late run, and he scored with a left foot finish. The match ended 1–1 after extra-time and Chelsea eventually lost 6–5 on penalties. He was later named [[UEFA Club Football Awards|UEFA Club Midfielder of the Year]]. [[File:Frank Lampard 2008.jpg|thumb|upright|Lampard playing for Chelsea in 2008]] On 13 August 2008, Lampard signed a new five-year contract with Chelsea worth £39.2 million, making him the highest-paid Premier League player.{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/sports/story.asp?file=/2008/8/15/sports/22088226&sec=sports |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080816042058/http://thestar.com.my/sports/story.asp?file=%2F2008%2F8%2F15%2Fsports%2F22088226&sec=sports |url-status=dead |archivedate=16 August 2008 |title=Lamps signs mega deal |accessdate=13 August 2008 |publisher=Malaysian Star Online |date=13 August 2008 }} He started the [[2008–09 Premier League|2008–09 season]] by scoring five goals in his first eleven league matches. He scored the 150th goal of his club career with a goal against Manchester City in the [[Premier League]]. In October 2008, in the Premier League he scored a chipped goal against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] with his left foot; he unleashed a chip from 20 yards that curled and swerved and fooled the goalkeeper as it went into the net. [[FIFA World Cup]]-winning coach [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] said after the game, "It was the best goal I have seen, my vote for World Player of the year award will go to him, only a player with his intelligence could have done that."{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/premierleague/3280485/Frank-Lampard-and-Chelsea-put-a-stop-to-Hulls-capital-gains-Football.html|title=Frank Lampard and Chelsea put a stop to Hull's capital gains|date=29 October 2008|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=13 September 2014}} Lampard scored his hundredth career Premier League goal in a 5–0 victory over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 2 November.{{cite news| date=2 November 2008| url=http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/news/312040/scolari-hails-centurion-lampard| title=Scolari hails centurion Lampard| publisher=The World Game| accessdate=5 May 2014| agency=PA Sport| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508160858/http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/news/312040/scolari-hails-centurion-lampard| archivedate=8 May 2014| url-status=dead| df=dmy-all}} Eighteen of Lampard's hundred goals were penalties.{{cite news | date=6 November 2008| url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1445574 | archive-url=https://archive.today/20140508101250/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1445574 | url-status=dead | archivedate=8 May 2014 | title=THE LAMPARD 100 GOAL PUZZLE – PART TWO | publisher=Chelsea FC | accessdate=8 May 2014 }} He was named Premier League Player of the Month for the third time in his career in [[2008–09 Premier League#Monthly awards|October]].{{cite Then in the fourth round of the FA Cup, he scored a free-kick from 35 yards against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]. Then he provided two assists in the next game against Arsenal in FA Cup semi-finals which Chelsea won 2–1. Lampard finished the season with 20 goals and 19 assists.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Lampard's 20th goal of the season was the winning goal in the [[2009 FA Cup Final|FA Cup Final]] against Everton, with a left-foot shot from long-range. He repeated the corner flag celebration his father had done after scoring the winning goal in the [[1979–80 FA Cup]] semi-final second leg against Everton. It was the fourth consecutive season that he scored 20 or more goals.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He was later named Chelsea's Player of the Year for the third time. Lampard started the [[2009–10 Chelsea F.C. season|2009–10 season]] by scoring against Manchester United, in the [[2009 FA Community Shield|2009 Community Shield]], in the 72nd minute. The match ended 2–2, and Lampard scored in its penalty shootout which they won 4–1. He scored his 133rd goal for Chelsea in a Champions League match against [[Atlético Madrid]] on 21 October 2009, which moved him up to fifth among the club's all-time goalscorers. He had been struggling to score the number of goals he had in the past seasons, however this soon changed as he scored two goals in the 5–0 defeat of Blackburn on 24 October 2009. On 30 October, he was nominated for the [[FIFA World Player of the Year]] award for the sixth-straight year.{{citation needed|date=June 2019}} [[File:Frank Lampard 2010.JPG|thumb|upright|Lampard celebrating after winning the [[Premier League]] title with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]]] On 16 December, Lampard scored a crucial 79th minute winning goal against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] and on 20 December, Lampard scored a penalty against his former club West Ham in a 1–1 draw, however he had to take his spot-kick three times due to players running into the box too early, he nonetheless scored all three. In Chelsea's 7–2 thrashing of Sunderland in January 2010, Lampard scored twice to add to his league tally. On 27 January 2010, Lampard again scored two goals, in Chelsea's 3–0 win over [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in the [[2009–10 Premier League|Premier League]]. On 27 February, Lampard yet again scored twice against Manchester City but despite his contribution Chelsea went on to lose the game 4–2 at home, for the first time in 38 games. Lampard, for the second time in his career, hit four goals in one match against Aston Villa on 27 March 2010 to bring his goal tally past 20, for the fifth-consecutive season. This also brought him his 151st Chelsea goal, and it put him as the club's third highest scorer ever, overtaking [[Peter Osgood]]'s record of 150. Lampard scored in a 3–0 win, again over Aston Villa, in the 2010 FA Cup semi-final.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8587517.stm|title=Chelsea 7 – 1 Aston Villa|date=27 March 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 March 2010|first=Phil|last=McNulty|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216115834/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8587517.stm|archive-date=16 February 2010|url-status=live}} Lampard reached 20 Premier League goals for the first time when he scored twice against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in Chelsea's 7–0 win on 25 April 2010. This milestone also represented the first time he had hit 25 in all competitions in a season. On 2 May, Lampard scored against Liverpool in the second last game of the season to give Chelsea a vital three points that took them to the top of the league by a single point. He scored one and assisted two other goals in the final match of the season where Chelsea thrashed Wigan Athletic 8–0 at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] to win the 2009–10 Premier League title and give him a remarkable 27 goals in the season.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8663686.stm|title=Chelsea 8 – 0 Wigan|date=9 May 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 May 2010|first=Phil|last=McNulty|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714160702/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8663686.stm|archive-date=14 July 2017|url-status=live}} Lampard ended his season lifting the [[2009–10 FA Cup|2010 FA Cup]] as Chelsea beat Portsmouth 1–0 in the final. On 12 May 2014, Lampard was named in the 23-man England squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/27362447 | title=World Cup 2014: England name Ross Barkley in squad | publisher=BBC Sport | date=12 May 2014 | accessdate=3 August 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306091010/http://www.bbc.com/sport/football/27362447 | archive-date=6 March 2016 | url-status=live }} and a week later he was named vice-captain.{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/world-cup/27460732 | title=Frank Lampard: England midfielder named vice-captain | publisher=BBC Sport | date=18 May 2014 | accessdate=3 August 2014 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140725031454/http://www.bbc.com/sport/world-cup/27460732 | archivedate=25 July 2014 | df=dmy-all }} On 24 June, for the last game of the group stage, Lampard captained his England side to draw with [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] 0–0.{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25285354 | title=England's World Cup ended without even the scant consolation of a victory as they played out a tame draw with Costa Rica in Belo Horizonte. | publisher=BBC Sport | date=24 June 2014 | accessdate=3 August 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130103403/http://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25285354 | archive-date=30 November 2016 | url-status=live }} On 26 August 2014, Lampard announced that he had retired from international football. It was the biggest defeat for a Chelsea manager in their first game since [[Danny Blanchflower]]'s team was beaten 7–2 by [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in December 1978.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/49314696|title=Man Utd 4-0 Chelsea: Damning scoreline but some positives for Lampard's Blues|date=11 August 2019|website=BBC Sport|access-date=12 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190812121452/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/49314696|archive-date=12 August 2019|url-status=live}} In Lampard's second competitive game with Chelsea, they lost again, this time against [[Liverpool F.C|Liverpool]] in the [[2019 UEFA Super Cup]] 2–2 after extra time, losing 5–4 on penalties. On 24 August 2019, Lampard obtained his first win as a Chelsea manager in the Premier League against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], in a 2–3 away win.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2019/aug/24/norwich-city-v-chelsea-premier-league-live|title=Full-time: Norwich City 2-3 Chelsea|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 August 2019|access-date=24 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190824135003/https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2019/aug/24/norwich-city-v-chelsea-premier-league-live|archive-date=24 August 2019|url-status=live}} On 25 September 2019, Chelsea picked up their first home win under Lampard's tenure beating [[EFL League Two|League Two]] side [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] 7–1 in the [[EFL Cup]]. His mother Pat died in April 2008 aged 58 as a result of [[pneumonia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/opinion/blogs/mirror-football-blog/The-mums-of-Cristiano-Ronaldo-George-Best-Ashley-Cole-Bobby-and-Jack-Charlton-Frank-Lampard-Jose-Antonio-Reyes-Theo-Walcott-and-more-Football-s-10-most-important-mothers-article351987.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=30 April 2016 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227021718/http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/opinion/blogs/mirror-football-blog/The-mums-of-Cristiano-Ronaldo-George-Best-Ashley-Cole-Bobby-and-Jack-Charlton-Frank-Lampard-Jose-Antonio-Reyes-Theo-Walcott-and-more-Football-s-10-most-important-mothers-article351987.html |archivedate=27 February 2014 |df=dmy }} Lampard's uncle is [[Harry Redknapp]] and his cousin is Redknapp's son [[Jamie Redknapp]]. In 2000, Lampard, Rio Ferdinand and [[Kieron Dyer]] appeared on a sex video that was filmed at the holiday resort of [[Ayia Napa]] in Cyprus. Channel 4 aired a brief clip as part of their 2004 documentary ''Sex, Footballers and Videotape'', claiming it was used to "remind the viewer that this is based on real life."{{cite news | date=15 August 2004 | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_20040815/ai_n12590242 | title=Channel 4 to show alleged Premiership sex video | publisher=CBS Interactive Inc | accessdate=23 November 2008 | first=Stephen | last=Naysmith | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222130151/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_20040815/ai_n12590242 | archive-date=22 December 2008 | url-status=live }} On 23 September 2001, Lampard, along with three other Chelsea players, was fined two weeks wages by the club for his behaviour whilst on a drinking binge on 12 September. Lampard and the others had abused American tourists at a Heathrow hotel, just 24 hours after the [[11 September attacks]]. A hotel manager stated: "they were utterly disgusting. They just didn't seem to care about what had happened".{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1341356/Chelsea-four-fined-for-drunken-abuse.html|title=Chelsea four fined for drunken abuse|date=23 September 2001|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|first=Alec|last=Marsh|location=London|accessdate=13 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812034116/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1341356/Chelsea-four-fined-for-drunken-abuse.html|archive-date=12 August 2014|url-status=live}} It was reported by [[Mensa International|Mensa]] in 2009 that Lampard showed an unusually high IQ score during neurological research carried out by the Chelsea doctor, Bryan English. English stated that "Frank Lampard scored one of the highest set of marks ever recorded by the company doing the tests".{{cite news|url=http://www.mensa.org.uk/cgi-bin/item.cgi?id=988&d=23&h=5&f=3|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130702232603/http://www.mensa.org.uk/cgi-bin/item.cgi?id=988&d=23&h=5&f=3|archivedate=2 July 2013| title=Footballer Frank Lampard reported to have a high IQ|publisher=Mensa|accessdate=12 March 2009}} He was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in the Queen's [[Birthday Honours]] on 13 June 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-33109755|title=Birthday Honours 2015: Van Morrison and Kevin Spacey head list|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=13 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612220302/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-33109755|archive-date=12 June 2015|url-status=live}} Lampard published his autobiography, ''Totally Frank'', in 2006. He has written a series of children's novels about a footballer, Frankie, and his adventures with his magic football.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2013/jun/01/frank-lampard-interview-book-frankies-magic-football|title=Frank Lampard interview: 'It was very difficult for me to write a kids' book'|date=1 June 2013|first=Aida|last=Edemariam|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=2 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103004924/https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2013/jun/01/frank-lampard-interview-book-frankies-magic-football|archive-date=3 January 2017|url-status=live}} ===Relationships=== Lampard lives in [[Surrey]] and London. He has two daughters with his former [[fiancée]], Spanish model Elen Rivas, Luna (born 22 August 2005) and Isla (born 20 May 2007).{{cite news|url=http://www.nowmagazine.co.uk/celebrity-news/237650/celebrity-news-elen-rives-gives-birth-hours-after-frank-wins-the-cup|title=Rives gives birth to footballer's second daughter|publisher=nowmagazine.co.uk|accessdate=8 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508163632/http://www.nowmagazine.co.uk/celebrity-news/237650/celebrity-news-elen-rives-gives-birth-hours-after-frank-wins-the-cup|archive-date=8 May 2014|url-status=live}} On 24 April 2009, Lampard was involved in a radio confrontation with [[James O'Brien (radio presenter)|James O'Brien]] on the London radio station [[LBC 97.3]].{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/lampard-vents-anger-at-heartless-comments-live-on-radio-1673790.html | title=Lampard vents anger at 'heartless' comments live on radio | newspaper=The Independent | date=24 April 2009 | accessdate=25 April 2009 | location=London | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426033402/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/lampard-vents-anger-at-heartless-comments-live-on-radio-1673790.html | archive-date=26 April 2009 | url-status=live }} Newspapers had reported that following Lampard's split from Rivas their children were living with her in a small flat while Lampard had converted their family home into a [[bachelor pad]]. Lampard phoned in, objecting to criticism and asserting that he had fought "tooth and nail" to keep his family together.{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/frank-lampards-call-to-lbc-the-full-transcript-1673885.html | title=Frank Lampard's call to LBC: The full transcript | newspaper=The Independent | date=24 April 2009 | accessdate=25 April 2009 | location=London | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426033302/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/frank-lampards-call-to-lbc-the-full-transcript-1673885.html | archive-date=26 April 2009 | url-status=live }} Lampard married [[Christine Lampard|Christine Bleakley]], a Northern Irish broadcaster, on 20 December 2015.
